tit.e: Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district)
Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district)
Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district)

sen.j: 熊襲（くまそ）とは、日本の記紀神話に登場する一族名。
sen.e: Kumaso is a name for the family that appear in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and the Japanese mythology.
Kumaso is a name for the family that appear in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and the Japanese mythology.
Kumaso is a name for the family that appear in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and the Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 九州南部に本拠地を構え、ヤマト王権に抵抗した一族名で、地域名を意味するとされる語である。
sen.e: The family was based in the southern part of Kyushu District, resisting Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty), and the name is said to have meant the area.
The family was based in the southern part of Kyushu District, resisting Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty), and the name is said to have meant the area.
The family was based in the southern part of Kyushu District, resisting Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty), and the name is said to have meant the area.

sen.j: 日本書紀には熊襲と表記され、古事記には熊曾と表記される。
sen.e: In Nihonshoki, it was written as Kumaso (熊襲), while in Kojiki, it was written as Kumaso (熊曾).
In Nihonshoki, it was written as Kumaso (熊襲), while in Kojiki, it was written as Kumaso (熊曾).
In Nihonshoki, it was written as Kumaso (熊襲), while in Kojiki, it was written as Kumaso (熊曾).

sen.j: 肥後国球磨郡（くまぐん。現熊本県人吉市周辺。球磨川上流域）から大隅国贈於郡（そおぐん。現鹿児島県霧島市周辺。現在の曽於市、曽於郡とは領域を異にする）に居住した部族である。
sen.e: They are a tribe who lived from Kuma County, Higo Province (around the present Hitoyoshi City, Kumamoto Prefecture, the upper reaches of the Kuma-gawa river) to Soo County, Osumi Province (around the present Kirishima City, Kagoshima Prefecture. It is a different area from the present Soo County, Soo City).
sen.cmt: ５つに分かれていたセルを統合一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They are a tribe who lived from Kuma County, Higo Province (around the present Hitoyoshi City, Kumamoto Prefecture, the upper reaches of the Kuma-gawa river) to Soo County, Osumi Province (around the present Kirishima City, Kagoshima Prefecture. It is a different area from the present Soo County, Soo City).

They are a tribe who lived from Kuma County, Higo Province (around the present Hitoyoshi City, Kumamoto Prefecture, the upper reaches of the Kuma-gawa river) to Soo County, Osumi Province (around the present Kirishima City, Kagoshima Prefecture. It is a different area from the present Soo County, Soo City).

sen.j: ヤマト王権への臣従後は、「隼人」として仕えたと言うのが現在の通説である（津田左右吉ら）。
sen.e: Today it is generally considered that after they became followers of Yamato sovereignty, they served as 'Hayato' (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) (Sokichi TSUDA and others).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Today it is generally considered that after they became followers of Yamato sovereignty, they served as 'Hayato' (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) (Sokichi TSUDA and others).
Today it is generally considered that after they became followers of Yamato sovereignty, they served as 'Hayato' (an ancient tribe in Kyushu) (Sokichi TSUDA and others).

sen.j: なお、隼人研究家の中村明蔵は、球磨地方と贈於地方の考古学的異質性から、熊襲の本拠は、都城地方や贈於地方のみであり、「クマ」は勇猛さを意味する美称であるとの説を唱えている。
sen.e: Akizo NAKAMURA, a scholar of Hayato, advocated a theory that the base of Kumaso was only the areas of Miyakonojo and Soo from the archeological difference of Miyakonojo and Soo areas, and 'Kuma' was a eulogistic name to indicate dauntlessness.

Akizo NAKAMURA, a scholar of Hayato, advocated a theory that the base of Kumaso was only the regions of Miyakonojo and Soo from the archeological difference of Kuma and Soo regions, and 'Kuma' was a eulogistic name to indicate dauntlessness.
sen.cmt: MiyakonojoをKumaに訂正し、地方を統一用語のregionに訂正しました。
sen.e: Akizo NAKAMURA, a scholar of Hayato, advocated a theory that the base of Kumaso was only the regions of Miyakonojo and Soo from the archeological difference of Kuma and Soo regions, and 'Kuma' was a eulogistic name to indicate dauntlessness.

sen.j: また、魏志倭人伝中の狗奴国をクマソの国であるとする説が、内藤湖南、津田左右吉、井上光貞らにより唱えられている。
sen.e: Moreover, Konan NAITO, Sokichi TSUDA, and Mitsusada INOUE claimed that Kunakoku mentioned in Gishiwajinden (literally, an 'Account of the Wa' in "The History of the Wei Dynasty") was the province of Kumaso.

Moreover, Konan NAITO, Sokichi TSUDA, and Mitsusada INOUE claimed that Kunakoku mentioned in Gishiwajinden (literally, an 'Account of the Wa' in "The History of the Wei Dynasty") was the province of Kumaso.

Moreover, Konan NAITO, Sokichi TSUDA, and Mitsusada INOUE claimed that Kunakoku mentioned in Gishiwajinden (literally, an 'Account of the Wa' in "The History of the Wei Dynasty") was the province of Kumaso.

sen.j: ただし、この説と邪馬台国九州説とは一致するものではない。
sen.e: However, this theory doe not necessarily correspond to a theory of Yamatai Kingdom located in Kyushu area.
However, this theory does not necessarily correspond to a theory of Yamatai Kingdom located in Kyushu area.
However, this theory does not necessarily correspond to a theory of Yamatai Kingdom located in Kyushu area.

sen.j: 5世紀ごろまでにヤマト政権に服属し、隼人となったと言うのが通説。
sen.e: It is generally known that they were subjected to Yamato administration by the fifth century and became Hayato.
It is generally known that they were subjected to Yamato administration by the fifth century and became Hayato.
It is generally known that they were subjected to Yamato administration by the fifth century and became Hayato.

tit.e: A myth of Kuni-umi (the birth of Japan)
A myth of Kuni-umi (the birth of Japan)
A myth of Kuni-umi (the birth of Japan)

sen.j: 古事記・国産み神話においては、四国の次、壱岐の前に生まれた筑紫島（九州）の四面のひとつとして語られ、別名を「建日別（タケヒワケ）」といったとされる。
sen.e: According to a myth of Kuni-umi in Kojiki, Kumaso was told as one of the four areas of Tsukushi no shima Island (Kyushu), which was born after Shikoku and before Iki Island, and its another name was said to be 'Takehiwake.'

According to a myth of Kuni-umi in Kojiki, Kumaso was told as one of the four areas of Tsukushi no shima Island (Kyushu), which was born after Shikoku and before Iki Island, and its another name was said to be 'Takehiwake.'

According to a myth of Kuni-umi in Kojiki, Kumaso was told as one of the four areas of Tsukushi no shima Island (Kyushu), which was born after Shikoku and before Iki Island, and its another name was said to be 'Takehiwake.'

sen.j: 次生、筑紫島。
sen.e: Next, Tsuku no shima Island was born.
Next, Tsuku no shima Island was born.
Next, Tsuku no shima Island was born.

sen.j: 此島亦、身一而、有面四。
sen.e: This island also had one body and four faces.
This island also had one body and four faces.
This island also had one body and four faces.

sen.j: 面毎有名。
sen.e: Each face had a name.
Each face had a name.
Each face had a name.

sen.j: 故、筑紫国謂、白日別。
sen.e: Tsukushi Province was called Shirahiwake.
Tsukushi Province was called Shirahiwake.
Tsukushi Province was called Shirahiwake.

sen.j: 豊国、言、豊日別。
sen.e: Toyo Province was called Toyohiwake.
Toyo Province was called Toyohiwake.
Toyo Province was called Toyohiwake.

sen.j: 肥国、言、建日向日豊久士比泥別。
sen.e: Hi Province was called Takehi Mukahi Toyokujihinewake.
Hi Province was called Takehi Mukahi Toyokujihinewake.
Hi Province was called Takehi Mukahi Toyokujihinewake.

sen.j: 熊曾国、言、建日別。
sen.e: Kumaso was called Takehiwake.
Kumaso was called Takehiwake.
Kumaso was called Takehiwake.

sen.j: 南九州がヤマト王権に臣従する過程が記紀神話に語られたもの。
sen.e: It is a myth told in Kojiki and Nihonshoki, which concerns the process of the southern Kyushu's serving Yamato sovereignty.
It is a myth told in Kojiki and Nihonshoki, which concerns the process of the southern Kyushu's serving Yamato sovereignty.
It is a myth told in Kojiki and Nihonshoki, which concerns the process of the southern Kyushu's serving Yamato sovereignty.

sen.j: 古事記には、景行天皇の皇子であるヤマトタケルによるクマソタケル（熊襲建、川上梟師）の征伐譚が記されている。
sen.e: Kojiki contains a tale in which Yamato Takeru, an Imperial prince of Emperor Keiko, subjugated Kumaso Takeru (Kawakami Takeru).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kojiki contains a tale in which Yamato Takeru, an Imperial prince of Emperor Keiko, subjugated Kumaso Takeru (Kawakami Takeru).
Kojiki contains a tale in which Yamato Takeru, an Imperial prince of Emperor Keiko, subjugated Kumaso Takeru (Kawakami Takeru).

sen.j: 日本書紀においては、それに加え、ヤマトタケルに先立つ景行天皇自身の征討伝説が記される。
sen.e: In addition, Nihonshoki tells a legend of Emperor Keiko's subjugation that had been conducted before Yamato Takeru.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Nihonshoki tells a legend of Emperor Keiko's subjugation that had been conducted before Yamato Takeru.
In addition, Nihonshoki tells a legend of Emperor Keiko's subjugation that had been conducted before Yamato Takeru.

sen.j: 特に前者は、当時小碓命と名乗ったヤマトタケルが、女装しクマソタケル兄弟の寝所に忍び込み、これらを討ち、その際に「タケル」の名を弟タケルより献上されたという神話で有名である。
sen.e: Especially the former is famous as a myth in which Yamato Takeru, who called himself Osu no Mikoto in those days, dressed up as a woman, sneaked into a bedchamber of Kumaso Takeru brothers and killed them, then he was given the name of younger brother Takeru at that time.

Especially the former is famous as a myth in which Yamato Takeru, who called himself Osu no Mikoto in those days, dressed up as a woman, sneaked into a bedchamber of Kumaso Takeru brothers and killed them, then he was given the name of younger brother Takeru at that time.

Especially the former is famous as a myth in which Yamato Takeru, who called himself Osu no Mikoto in those days, dressed up as a woman, sneaked into a bedchamber of Kumaso Takeru brothers and killed them, then he was given the name of younger brother Takeru at that time.

tit.j: 景行天皇九州征伐神話
tit.e: A myth of Emperor Keiko's Kyushu conquest
A myth of Emperor Keiko's Kyushu conquest
A myth of Emperor Keiko's Kyushu conquest

sen.j: 日本書紀に記述される神話。
sen.e: It is a myth described in Nihonshoki.
